Award.AwardTitle: Synthetic Integration of Inorganic-Organic Functionality in Hybrid Semiconductors based on Chalcogenide Clusters
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

By integrating synthetic and structural principles from several fields including metal chalcogenide cluster chemistry, coordination chemistry, and nanoporous solids, this research supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program seeks to employ complex multi-component and multi-step co-assembly processes to create a new generation of supramolecular chalcogenide clusters and their organized assemblies with organic functional moieties. Specifically, the proposed research seeks to utilize structural and functional diversity of organic molecules to control structures of chalcogenide clusters and extended frameworks and to enhance their electrooptical properties and functionalities. To minimize the possibility for phase separation common in multi-component systems, inorganic and organic components will be chosen so that each component plays a unique role that is complementary to other components, The PI will also seek to pursue metal chalcogenide cluster research in a direction towards the modular synthesis, by developing methods to create pre-designed discrete chalcogenide clusters. The use of pre-assembled supramolecular units not only simplifies the co-assembly process, but also allows the use of milder synthetic conditions to access metastable phase domains, which is particularly desirable for co-assembly into topologies with open architecture.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Through this proposed research, new areas of cross-disciplinary research bordering various fields such as semiconducting nanoparticles, chalcogenide molecular clusters, coordination polymers, and traditional zeolites will be developed. New materials developed in this project will include crystalline high-surface-area semiconductors with potential applications in various energy and environmental science related areas. UC Riverside has the most diverse student population among UC campuses. Undergraduate research is highly supported in the PI's group. The PI is actively involved in various educational and training programs for undergraduate and high school students. The proposed project can be used to infuse a wide and highly diverse student audience with enthusiasm for careers in materials chemistry. The project combines diversity in materials types and various measurement techniques and aims to develop new materials for energy or environmental science related applications. It will therefore provide excellent training opportunities for students in synthesis, structural characterization, and property measurements and prepare them for a challenging, but rewarding career in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this project is to integrate synthetic and structural principles recently developed from metal chalcogenide cluster chemistry and nanoporous solids (including coordination polymers) to create a new class of cluster-based semiconducting open framework materials and to develop a new frontier of synthetic chemistry by utilizing compositional, structural, and functional diversity of chalcogenide clusters and organic molecules to control the synthesis process and structures and to modify optical and electrooptical properties of resulting crystalline porous semiconducting materials for different energy and environment related applications. 

Intellectual merit:  Through this project, new areas of inter-disciplinary research at interfaces between semiconductor nanoparticles and nanoporous solids, and between traditional chalcogenide frameworks and coordination polymers, have been developed. The research activity explores a new frontier dealing with unique porous and semiconducting materials based on supramolecular building blocks. The integration of size-tunable semiconducting nanoclusters with functional organic moieties makes it possible to produce materials with unprecedented structural, optical, and electronic properties due to synergetic effects resulting from uniform molecular-level integration of both components. These materials could integrate semiconductivity and uniform porosity and have potential applications in areas such as photocatalysis, photovoltaics, solid-state lighting, and sorption-based sensing or gas separation as well as environmental applications. The research activity generates a whole body of new knowledge on synthetic and structural chemistry of chalcogenide clusters interacting with various types of cationic, anionic, and neutral organic moieties that play diverse and complementary roles in the co-assembly process.

Broader impacts: The proposed activities allow the PI’s group to further develop state-of-the-art synthetic and instrumental capability that help broaden teaching and research opportunities for the diverse student population and to attract talented undergraduate and minority students to participate in chemical and materials related research. UC Riverside has the most diverse student population among UC campuses. Undergraduate research is highly supported in the PI’s group. The PI teaches large low-level undergraduate courses and also upper-level undergraduate and graduate courses. The project activities and results have been used as examples to show student with enthusiasm for careers in chemistry the principle and beauty of chemistry materials research. The project combines diversity in materials types and various measurement techniques and serves well for training students in energy or environment-related applications. It therefore provides excellent training opportunities for students in synthesis, structural characterization, and property measurements and prepares them for a challenging career in science. Their research experiences could have a major impact in shaping these students’ scientific career. Research results have been broadly disseminated through timely publications and research presentations. All crystal structural data have been deposited in databases accessible to the public.
